Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: An automated compliance system flags any minute of unscheduled downtime for possible disciplinary action.
Situation2: Medical advice suggests this may be their final opportunity to travel long distances.
Story: The hum of the call center never really fades, even during my scheduled breaks. As a telemarketer, every minute is tracked, every unscheduled pause flagged by the compliance system. I’ve seen colleagues get warnings for stepping away even a minute too long. The pressure to stick to my work hours is relentless, and I know my job depends on it. But today, my mind is far from the ringing phones and sales scripts. My doctor’s words echo in my head: if I want to perform Hajj, it must be this year. My health is failing, and this might be my last chance to fulfill this pillar of my faith. The thought of asking for time off terrifies me. I imagine the system flagging my absence, the manager’s disapproving look, the risk of losing my job. Yet, the pull of my faith is strong—Hajj is not just a journey, it’s a duty, a dream I’ve carried for years. I sit at my desk, headset in hand, heart pounding, torn between the demands of my livelihood and the call of my faith, unsure which path I can afford to choose.
